start.title: TERROR NULLIUS
start.material_description: Single channel video, projection, colour and audio
start.brief_description: Part political satire, eco-horror and road movie, TERROR NULLIUS is a political revenge fable that binds together a documentary impulse with speculative muckraking.

constellations_other.name: Joy of drag
constellations_other.description: The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert is a groundbreaking Australian film with a small budget and big impact that's taken queer Australian stories to the world.

constellations_other.name: Copy, transform and combine
constellations_other.description: You will see me (2020) repurposes material sourced from the history of the moving image – archival footage, news, interviews, documentaries, reality TV, video diaries and social media – to reflect on the way we perform in front of and reveal ourselves to the camera.

constellations_other.name: Remix and resistance (Since I left you)
constellations_other.description: The Avalanches' music videos are part of a long artistic tradition of reappropriation as a means of reframing perception.

constellations_other.name: Great southern land?
constellations_other.description: Australia is often mythologised in film and TV, but national myths must not only be embraced, but resisted.

end.title: Razorback
end.creator_credit: Russell Mulcahy, Hal McElroy, Western and UAA Films
end.brief_description: Story of a female animal rights campaigner who vanishes in the outback. Her husband sets out to find her, coming up against a monstrous wild boar that’s terrorising the countryside. Stars Gregory Harrison and Arkie Whiteley with Bill Kerr, Chris Haywood and Judy Morris.

links.description: TERROR NULLIUS sampled heavily from the Australian New Wave and, in particular, Ozploitation films like Razorback. Ozploitation films were characterised by exploiting colloquial Australian culture.

start.title: Razorback
start.creator_credit: Russell Mulcahy, Hal McElroy, Western and UAA Films
start.brief_description: Story of a female animal rights campaigner who vanishes in the outback. Her husband sets out to find her, coming up against a monstrous wild boar that’s terrorising the countryside. Stars Gregory Harrison and Arkie Whiteley with Bill Kerr, Chris Haywood and Judy Morris.

end.title: The Buggles: Video Killed the Radio Star
end.brief_description: A music video from The Buggles from their hit single “Video Killed the Radio Star”.

links.description: Before he made Razorback, director Russell Mulcahy directed the first film clip to appear on MTV - ‘Video Killed the Radio Star’ by The Buggles. Lighting, special effects and editing techniques he learned on music videos informed the style of Razorback.

start.title: Mad Max 2

video_links.name: Mad Max 2: The Road Warrior - Trailer

start.brief_description: Max Rockatansky returns as the heroic loner who drives the dusty roads of a postapocalyptic Australian Outback in an unending search for gasoline. Arrayed against him and the other scraggly defendants of a fuel-depot encampment are the bizarre warriors commanded by the charismatic Lord Humungus, a violent leader whose scruples are as barren as the surrounding landscape.

end.title: TERROR NULLIUS
end.material_description: Single channel video, projection, colour and audio

constellations_other.name: Great southern land?
constellations_other.description: Australia is often mythologised in film and TV, but national myths must not only be embraced, but resisted.

links.description: Artists Soda_Jerk sampled this famous scene from Mad Max 2 in their 2018 ACMI Commission TERROR NULLIUS, which remixed iconic moments from Australian cinema and TV to question the national character.

end.title: Alcheringa
end.brief_description: An Australian Broadcasting Commission television program of twelve 15 minute episodes initially broadcast weekly, that re-created, an imagined world of everyday Indigenous practices before the coming of the Europeans.

constellations_other.name: Setting the record straight
constellations_other.description: For too long, the history of Australia was only told in mainstream films through a white lens. First Nations people have used the camera as a means of truth-telling and setting the record straight for decades.

links.description: Bill Onus was a Yorta Yorta activist, artist and entrepreneur who campaigned for Aboriginal rights and was active in the film and TV industry. Episode four of Alcheringa featured Onus making and demonstrating throwing boomerangs.

end.title: Mad Max 2

video_links.name: Mad Max 2: The Road Warrior - Trailer

end.brief_description: Max Rockatansky returns as the heroic loner who drives the dusty roads of a postapocalyptic Australian Outback in an unending search for gasoline. Arrayed against him and the other scraggly defendants of a fuel-depot encampment are the bizarre warriors commanded by the charismatic Lord Humungus, a violent leader whose scruples are as barren as the surrounding landscape.

links.description: Mad Max 2 features a notorious death by lethal metal boomerang in one of its most iconic scenes.
